meta.name: Posthumanism Lens
meta.description: An interpretive lens that decenters the human, attending to more-than-human relations in curriculum-making
notes: This lens suspends canonical structures entirely
It repositions humans as one actor among many
Agency is understood as distributed, not owned

main_view.title: Curriculum as Entanglement
main_view.subtitle: A posthuman perspective

declarations.statement: Curriculum is not a stable object.
declarations.elaboration: It does not reside in documents, plans, or standards alone. It emerges through relations.

declarations.statement: Learning is not acquired or transmitted.
declarations.elaboration: It is produced in events‚Äîmoments of intra-action among people, materials, technologies, time, and affect.
Humans are participants, not origins. Intention is not the sole driver of meaning.
Plans are provisional. What emerges cannot be fully predicted or controlled.

exploratory_questions: What if curriculum happens through us, not by us?
What actors are present but overlooked?
How do materials, spaces, and rhythms participate in learning?
What would it mean to attune rather than control?
How might we design for negotiation rather than optimization?
main_view.closing_reflection: This lens does not propose a new curriculum framework. It temporarily withholds framework thinking itself‚Äîto ask different questions.

philosophical_orientation.curriculum_as: Emergent, relational, eventful‚Äîproduced through intra-action among people, tools, spaces, discourses, time, and affect

posthuman_actors.label: Material Actors
posthuman_actors.definition: Physical objects and environments that participate in curriculum enactment
posthuman_actors.agency_framing: Materials afford, constrain, and shape what becomes possible. They are not neutral tools but active participants in learning.
common_influences: Physical affordances enable or limit exploration

posthuman_actors.label: Technological Actors
posthuman_actors.definition: Digital systems, platforms, and algorithms that mediate and co-produce curriculum
posthuman_actors.agency_framing: Technologies are not mere delivery mechanisms. They actively shape what counts as learning, who is visible, and what pathways are possible.
common_influences: Algorithms prioritize certain content or behaviors
Data systems define what is measured and valued

posthuman_actors.label: Temporal Actors
posthuman_actors.definition: Time structures, rhythms, and pacing that regulate curriculum flow
posthuman_actors.agency_framing: Time is not a neutral container. Temporal structures actively produce urgency, depth, and what gets attended to or neglected.
common_influences: Pacing determines coverage vs. depth trade-offs
Rhythms establish what feels normal or rushed

posthuman_actors.label: Affective Actors
posthuman_actors.definition: Emotional climates, tensions, and motivational forces that permeate learning environments
posthuman_actors.agency_framing: Affect is not merely internal to individuals. It circulates and shapes what becomes thinkable, doable, and learnable.

posthuman_actors.label: Ecological Actors
posthuman_actors.definition: Environmental, spatial, and sustainability conditions that shape curriculum possibilities
posthuman_actors.agency_framing: Ecology is not just context. Spaces and environments actively invite or discourage certain forms of learning and being.
common_influences: Space design shapes movement and interaction
Environmental conditions affect focus and wellbeing

Name non-human actors explicitly when relevant
Avoid linear cause-effect framings where possible

perennialism.posthuman_reading: Viewed through a posthuman lens, perennialism's enduring truths might be understood not as fixed essences but as stabilized network effects‚Äîideas that have persisted through particular material-discursive assemblages of texts, institutions, and practices.

progressivism.posthuman_reading: A posthuman reading foregrounds how 'child-centered' approaches distribute agency across materials, spaces, and relations. The child is not an autonomous learner but emerges through interaction with an arranged environment.

reconstructionism.posthuman_reading: Posthumanism might ask: who or what else is reconstructing society? This lens attends to how social change is produced through hybrid assemblages of human action, media technologies, environmental conditions, and affective intensities.

academic_rationalism.posthuman_reading: Academic disciplines are not purely human constructs but are stabilized through libraries, laboratories, peer review systems, citation networks, and material practices that exceed individual intention.

cognitive_processes.posthuman_reading: Cognition, in this reading, is not located solely in minds but is distributed across tools, representations, and environments. Thinking happens in the extended assemblage of human-tool-environment.

curriculum_as_technology.posthuman_reading: This conception already gestures toward non-human agency. Posthumanism intensifies this: the curriculum-as-technology is not simply a tool humans use but an actor that shapes what humans become.

guidance: Design shapes conditions, affordances, and constraints‚Äînot outcomes
Success is judged by responsiveness and sustainability of relations
Plans are provisional; outcomes are traces, not endpoints
Attend to what the design makes likely, not what it guarantees
questions_for_designers: What non-human actors will participate in this curriculum?
How might materials, technologies, or spaces shape what emerges?
What temporal rhythms are being installed, and what do they enable or foreclose?
How might affective climates be cultivated or disrupted?
What ecological conditions support or strain this design?

ui_guidance.disclaimer: This lens is a way of seeing, not a normative prescription. It destabilizes certainty to surface overlooked actors and relations.
